lines.content: # CS2113 Team Project (tP) - Project Planning and Standards

This document outlines the comprehensive planning structure, standards, and procedures for the CS2113 Team Project (tP). The tP follows a breadth-first iterative development approach, aiming to produce working versions of the product incrementally.
- Working MVP at each iteration end
- Every team member is equal in responsibility and accountability
- All members contribute ideas and solutions
- Higher risk of conflicts without clear authority figure
1. **Chief Programmer Team**: Single authoritative figure makes major decisions
2. **Strict Hierarchy Team**: Defined organization with clear reporting lines
Each important role must be assigned to one person (with optional backup):
- **Project Lead/Coordinator**: Overall project coordination, milestone tracking
- **Documentation Lead**: Ensures UG/DG consistency and completeness
- **Testing Lead**: Oversees test coverage and CI maintenance
- **Integration Lead**: Manages code integration and build stability
- **Quality Assurance**: Reviews code and ensures standards compliance
- Contribute to functional code (user-visible features preferred)
- Update User Guide and Developer Guide for added features
- **Functional Code**: Contribute to product features (user-visible preferred)
- **Feature Fit**: Enhancements must fit with product and have team consent
- **Work Distribution**: Divide work by features/enhancements, not components
- **Complete Ownership**: Handle all work related to your enhancement yourself
- **User Guide (UG)**: Update sections related to your enhancements
- **UML Diagrams**: Use at least 2 types of UML diagrams in DG updates
- **Proposed Features**: Can supplement with documented proposals if needed
- **Automated Tests**: Write evidence of automated testing capability
- **Test Coverage**: No minimum requirement, but sufficient to prevent regressions
- **Test Types**: Unit tests, integration tests, system tests as appropriate
- **Team Tasks**: Carry non-trivial share of team responsibilities
- **Code Reviews**: Review others' work and receive reviews
- Features integrate to form cohesive product
- Documentation maintains consistent style and presentation
- Equivalent to individual iP effort per team member
- No extra marks for exceeding requirements
- Better to improve other aspects (testing, documentation, reviews)
Using GitHub tools for comprehensive project tracking:
| WHAT needs to be done? | Issues |
| WHO should do tasks? | Issue assignees |
| WHEN to complete tasks? | Milestones with deadlines |
| HOW is task progressing? | Pull Requests |
| HOW is iteration progressing? | Milestones + Releases |
- **Task Size**: Small enough for one person, few hours
- **User Stories**: Format as "As a [user] I can [action] so that [benefit]"
- **Creator**: Preferably the person who will implement
- **Deadlines**: Set earlier than course deadlines for buffer
- **Branch**: Each PR from separate branch (forking workflow)
- **Issue Requirement**: Preferably link PRs to issues (not strictly required, but recommended for tracking)
- **Who Merges**: Up to team to decide (PR author, reviewer, team lead)
- **Discouraged**: Unilateral merging without reviews (unless trivial changes)
- **Keep Branches**: Don't delete after merge (grading requirement)
- **Sync Process**: Pull from team repo, merge master to feature branches
- **Packages**: All lowercase, use group/project name as root
- **Conditionals**: Always use braces, condition on separate line
- **Javadoc**: First sentence starts with verb (Returns, Adds, etc.)
* @param taskId The ID of the task
- Put every class in a package
- Array specifiers attach to type: `int[] array`, not `int array[]`
- Follow Google Java Style Guide for uncovered topics
- Focus on correctness, style, and maintainability
- Test classes in same package as SUT
- Update test files with new functionality
- ❌ Not using separate branches for each PR
- ❌ Everyone responsible for everything (no clear roles)
- ❌ Not carrying fair share of team tasks
2. Create feature branch for new work
- Missed deadlines: Reassign and adjust scope
*This document serves as the comprehensive guide for tP execution. Update as needed for team-specific adaptations while maintaining compliance with course requirements.*
FlowCLI is a fast, minimal CLI task manager for organizing projects and tasks.
FlowCLI allows you to manage projects and tasks via command line. Below are all available commands with examples.
- Expected Output: Confirmation of project added.
- Expected Output: Lists all projects with indices.
- Expected Output: Lists all tasks in the "work" project.
- Expected Output: Confirmation of project deleted.
- Expected Output: Confirmation of task added with priority and deadline.
- Expected Output: Task added with default medium priority and no deadline.
- Expected Output: Task 1 in "work" marked as done ([X]).
- Expected Output: Confirmation of task deleted.
- **Sort Tasks by Deadline**: `sort tasks by deadline ascending` or `sort tasks by deadline descending`
- Expected Output: All tasks sorted by deadline (ascending), showing project context (e.g., "work: finish report").
- **Sort Tasks by Priority**: `sort tasks by priority ascending` or `sort tasks by priority descending`
- Expected Output: All tasks sorted by priority (high to low), showing project context.
- **Filter Tasks by Priority**: `filter tasks by priority <value>`
- Expected Output: Only tasks with high priority, showing project context.
- **Filter Tasks by Project**: `filter tasks by project <name>`
- Expected Output: Only tasks from project "work", showing project context.
- Expected Output: Displays all available commands.
- Expected Output: Exits the application with goodbye message.
Prerequisites: JDK 17 (use the exact version), update Intellij to the most recent version.

1. **Ensure Intellij JDK 17 is defined as an SDK**, as described [here](https://www.jetbrains.com/help/idea/sdk.html#set-up-jdk) -- this step is not needed if you have used JDK 17 in a previous Intellij project.
1. **Import the project _as a Gradle project_**, as described [here](https://se-education.org/guides/tutorials/intellijImportGradleProject.html).

1. **Verify the setup**: After the importing is complete, locate the `src/main/java/seedu/flowcli/FlowCLI.java` file, right-click it, and choose `Run FlowCLI.main()`. If the setup is correct, you should see the welcome message and command prompt.

**Warning:** Keep the `src\main\java` folder as the root folder for Java files (i.e., don't rename those folders or move Java files to another folder outside of this folder path), as this is the default location some tools (e.g., Gradle) expect to find Java files.
* This project uses Gradle for build automation and dependency management. It includes a basic build script as well (i.e. the `build.gradle` file).
* If you are new to Gradle, refer to the [Gradle Tutorial at se-education.org/guides](https://se-education.org/guides/tutorials/gradle.html).
* To run _I/O redirection_ tests (aka _Text UI tests_), navigate to the `text-ui-test` and run the `runtest(.bat/.sh)` script.
* If you are new to JUnit, refer to the [JUnit Tutorial at se-education.org/guides](https://se-education.org/guides/tutorials/junit.html).
* A sample CheckStyle rule configuration is provided in this project.
* If you are new to Checkstyle, refer to the [Checkstyle Tutorial at se-education.org/guides](https://se-education.org/guides/tutorials/checkstyle.html).

The project uses [GitHub actions](https://github.com/features/actions) for CI. When you push a commit to this repo or PR against it, GitHub actions will run automatically to build and verify the code as updated by the commit/PR.
`/docs` folder contains a skeleton version of the project documentation.
Steps for publishing documentation to the public:
1. If you are using this project template for an individual project, go your fork on GitHub.
If you are using this project template for a team project, go to the team fork on GitHub.
1. Scroll down to the `GitHub Pages` section.
1. Optionally, use the `choose a theme` button to choose a theme for your documentation.

FlowCLI is a fast, minimal command-line interface (CLI) task manager that helps users organize tasks within projects. The application follows a clean architecture with separated concerns for commands, UI, data models, and exception handling.
**Description:** The main entry point of the application. Initializes all core components and starts the command processing loop.
- Creates `ConsoleUi` and passes the project list
**Description:** A simple data class that represents a parsed command with its type and arguments.
- `type`: The command type (LIST, MARK, UNMARK, ADD, DELETE, BYE, UNKNOWN)
- `arg`: The arguments associated with the command
Command cmd = new Command(CommandParser.Type.ADD, "project1 task description");
- Used by `CommandHandler` to determine what action to take
**Description:** Parses raw user input into structured `Command` objects. Identifies the command type and extracts arguments.
- Split input into command word and arguments
- Map command words to `Command.Type` enum values
- `parseIndexOrNull(String indexText, int maxIndex)`: Validates and converts string index to zero-based integer
- Used by `CommandHandler` to parse each line of user input
**Description:** Separates project names from task-related arguments. Determines if the first argument is a project name and splits the remaining text.
- Check if the first word matches an existing project name
- Set `targetProject` if found, or null if not
- Store remaining arguments for further processing
- Used by `CommandHandler` for all commands that need project context
- Enables commands to work with or without project context
**Description:** The command execution engine. Continuously reads user input, parses commands, and executes corresponding actions.
- Coordinate between parsing, business logic, and UI
- `list` - Show all projects or tasks in a project
- Uses `ArgumentParser` to extract project and arguments
- Calls `ProjectList` and `Project` methods to modify data
**Description:** Container class for all custom exception types used in the application. Each exception provides clear error messages to users.
- Thrown when: A command requires a project name but none was found
- Message: "Couldn't find any project with such name"
- Thrown when: Commands like `mark` or `delete` are missing an index
- Thrown when: Provided index is outside valid range
- Thrown when: Operations require projects but list is empty
- Message: "Your Project List is empty. Add a task first."
- Thrown when: Operations require tasks but list is empty
- Message: "Your Task list is empty. Add a task first."
- Thrown when: Task creation lacks description
- Message: "Bro stop trolling, you only entered the command and target project..."
- Thrown when: Command is not recognized
**Description:** Searches for projects whose names contain a specified search string. The search is case-insensitive.
- Return matching projects as a new `ProjectList`
ProjectList matches = filter.getMatchingTasks(); // Note: method name is misleading
// Returns all projects with "work" in their name (case-insensitive)
**Note:** The method `getMatchingTasks()` actually returns projects, not tasks. Consider renaming to `getMatchingProjects()` for clarity.
- Currently not used in `CommandHandler` but available for search functionality
**Description:** Represents a single project containing a collection of tasks. Each project has a unique name and manages its own `TaskList`.
- `projectTasks`: The list of tasks belonging to this project
Task deleted = project.deleteTask(0); // Deletes first task
**Description:** Manages the collection of all projects in the application. Provides methods to add, remove, and retrieve projects.
- Delete projects by index or reference
**Description:** Represents a single task with a description and completion status. This is the basic unit of work in the application.
**Description:** Manages a collection of tasks within a project. Provides CRUD operations for tasks.
**Description:** Handles all user interface interactions. Displays welcome messages, command results, project/task lists, and manages output formatting.
- Display ASCII art logo and welcome message
// Display task list for a project
- `showProjectList()`: List all projects with their tasks
- Used extensively by `CommandHandler` to display results
2. **CommandParser** parses command word and arguments → creates `Command`
4. **ArgumentParser** separates project name from remaining arguments
public enum Type { LIST, MARK, UNMARK, BYE, ADD, DELETE, FIND, UNKNOWN }
